title: 230 000 play park for grange is considered by council
story: Mid and East Antrim Borough Council have agreed a Business Case for a new pound, play and kick-about area for a rural hamlet outside Ballymena.The proposed development at The Grange would feature a range of dynamic play equipment and allow for children in the community to enjoy physical activity outdoors in a safe and inclusive environment.Following approval of the Business Case, a tender exercise for the project will commence in due course, councillors were told at this month’s Full Council meeting, which took place last night.Welcoming the progress in the new facility, Alderman William McNeilly, said: “I was delighted to propose that Council accept the Business Case for this much-needed development in the Grange area of Ballymena.OUTDOOR EXERCISE“The importance of play and outdoor exercise to the health and wellbeing of children and young people has never been more important and this new facility, when it is completed, will be an excellent addition to the area.”Councillor Brian Collins, who seconded the proposal, added: “Good quality play experiences have been shown to have a positive impact in all aspects of a child’s le and their personal development, so it is very welcome to see Council commit to investing in this proposed new facility.“I look forward to seeing how this project progresses and to the long-term benefits it will bring to the local community.”Bannside representative, Ald. Stewart McDonald also commended the plans. Posting a graphic of the proposals, he commented: “Finally, light at the end of the tunnel.”

title: minister s sweeping praise for council s campaign against litter
story: Mid and East Antrim Borough Council’s ongoing fightback against littering and waste crime has been praised by the Minister for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs, Edwin Poots MLA, during a visit to the area.Council Mayor Cllr Peter Johnston, and Officers from the Waste Services Team, welcomed the Minister, who inspected a fleet of new street sweepers funded by his department.The pound, state-of-the-art equipment forms another key part of Council’s commitment to tackling littering throughout the Borough.Council has also recently teamed up with Waste Investigations Support  Enforcementfor a yearlong trial to help prosecute those who flout the rules.Enforcement Officers are working in partnership with Council Officers and have powers to issue fixed penalty noticesto anyone failing to pick up after their dog or dropping litter in the street.VALUABLE RESOURCESpeaking following the DAERA Minister’s visit, Mayor Cllr Peter Johnston, said:“I was delighted to welcome Minister Poots to Ballymena and that he was able to see for himself the new street sweepers which are another major tool in Council’s efforts to keep our local environment clean and looking its best.“As a Council we are required to provide scheduled and reactive street cleansing across the Borough.“The compact sweeper will not only support the immediate demand on the service as a result of Covid, but also help us tackle the medium to longer term increase in cleansing regime required as a result of the phased lockdown easing over the coming months.“The sweeper is a valuable resource to help us keep the streets and paths clear of litter and dog foul, and the support of the Department and Minister Poots is very welcome.“We want all those who live, work and visit Mid and East Antrim Borough in the coming weeks and months to enjoy our beautul towns, villages and countryside, and every one of us has a role to play in that.”DAERA Minister Edwin Poots MLA said: “I am pleased that my Department has been able to provide pound, of funding to purchase state-of-the-art sweeper equipment.“Here in Northern Ireland we have some of the most stunning natural landscape in the world, and the scourge of littering and dog fouling is costing us all, not just in financial terms through our public services, but especially through the harm that is caused to our precious environment for current and future generations.“It was good to see how Mid and East Antrim Borough Council is tackling these problems and sending a clear message that our local communities are worth protecting.“As we begin to see the reopening of visitor attractions across Northern Ireland over coming weeks and months, it is crucial that we all do what we can to look after the places and spaces we call home.”In addition to the new street sweeping equipment and the rollout of the WISE enforcement team, Council is also working with Keep Northern Ireland Beautul to promote environmental awareness in local schools, while additional surveying across the Borough is helping to identy areas that need extra attention.Dog fouling and littering have seen an increase throughout the Covid- pandemic, while the level of PPE such as gloves and masks, has markedly risen.

title: murphy launches recruitment campaign for 500 civil service positions
story: Finance Minister Conor Murphy has launched a major Civil Service external recruitment campaign and is encouraging people to apply. Pictured - Finance Minister Conor Murphy with some current EOs and EOs - .Speaking as recruitment for around  positions gets underway, Minister Murphy said: “The Civil Service delivers a range of services to people and families. With posts available across a number of Departments this is an excellent opportunity for people who want to make a real contribution to society.”Encouraging applicants from a erse range of backgrounds, Murphy added: “The Civil Service should reflect the society it serves. I welcome applications from talented and motivated people regardless of their age, gender or gender identity, sexual orientation, religion, community background, disability or ethnicity.”The recruitment campaign is to fill approximately  positions at Executive Officergrades based in Civil Service Departments at a number of locations immediately as well as to create a waiting list of candidates to fill further vacancies that may arise during the le of this campaign. The first stage of the recruitment campaign for Executive Officer Grade  posts opened on Monday  May with applications for Executive Officer Grade  posts opening on Monday  May.For more details and to apply visit www.nicsrecruitment.org.uk. Completed application forms for EO must be submitted no later than  noon on Friday  May. The closing date for applications for EO must be submitted no later than  noon on Friday  May.

Credit: GettyAllan PrestonTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailFor Rory McIlroy and we Erica, the main order of business after celebrating his first win in  months was to comfort their eight-month old daughter Poppy.It was all too much for the tot, who found herself surrounded by cheering fans at the Wells Fargo Championship in North Carolina.Several well-known local parents told the Belfastthe public meltdown was a touching moment that seemed all too familiar.Two-time Olympic boxing bronze medallist Paddy Barnes recalled fleeing a restaurant when his daughter Eireann was two.I remember having my daughter out in Nando’s and she just squealed the place down,” he said.These two girls were coming over to me to help, but I just took her and split because everyone was looking at us.I felt really paranoid, because I felt like people were wanting us to shut up even though they were trying to help.I was just in a panic, I left with my dinner on the table. Now,my kids are crying, I wouldn’t mind as much because I’ve got more experience.”He added: “If I ever see parents with their kids crying out in public I just laugh because I can relate. There’s nothing you can do about it, it’s not the parents’ fault. Kids cry and there’s often nothing you can do about it.”On McIlroy, he said: “He’s very successful, so no doubt his baby will soon get used to it.”BBC presenting couple Connor Phillips and Holly Hamilton welcomed their son Fionn in January. Already behaving like a seasoned media professional, Connor said Fionn behaved perfectly at a recent event where his parents were working.He said: He times his little strops very well, just to make sure mummy and daddy look good. He has his moments too and can be a little a, so we do a lot of walking around the shore.Just today we were about a mile away from home and he unexpectedly woke up and he just wasn’t going back to sleep, full stop.”Asked how he deals with the stress of an upset child in public, he said: “I think back to my parentless self and think of how I might have reacted to seeing that. I might have rolled my eyes. But now as parents you go: ‘My God, the parents that have gone before me are absolute heroes’.I do think it’s the best thing in the world, though. He had a strop on the beach today and when we sat him up, he just seemed to say: ‘Thank you for that mummy and daddy’.”On McIlroy, he said: “I’m sure people think he has nannies and au pairs doing all the work. But I doubt that very much, I’m sure he’s a Holywood boy at heart looking after his wee man. I now have % empathy with parents, they’re terric, especially mums!” Comedians Diona Doherty and Sean Hegarty welcomed their daughter Winter five weeks ago. The Derry Girls and Give My Head Peace actress said feeling safe while out in public during the pandemic had been her biggest obstacle.“Today was the first day I took my daughter to the shopping centre, which was quite daunting. I know other parents who had babies during lockdown but haven’t really been anywhere for six months. That’s probably even scarier,” she said.Diona gave birth while having Covid, but now feels somewhat safer that both of them have some immunity.Any time we’re out for a walk it’s the same, it’s been cut short. Our baby has a set of lungs on her. Luckily I’m breastfeeding, so I can console her quite quickly. But you’re always planning ahead for the quickest route back.”Belfast Most ReadAdrian Dunbar and top Orangeman Mervyn Gibson split over Ireland in Sinn Fein ‘crushed our sister’: Family criticise Credit: Kevin Scott   Belfast Suzanne BreenTwitterEmailMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailWhen -year-old Kate Nicholl arrived in Belfast with her mother having fled Zimbabwe, she never dreamed she would end up its Lord Mayor. “My mum had £ in her purse. Without the help of the Gingerbread charity for single parents, I don’t know how we’d have coped,” she says. “We got a flat on the th floor of Riverdale House tower block in Dunmurry. It all seemed very grey. My whole world had collapsed. My parents’ marriage had broken up previously, and now we had left our home and were in a dferent country.When our belongings were shipped over, someone set fire to the boxes outside the flat. We literally lost everything, including photographs. I found it all very traumatic.”In three weeks’ time Katewill be installed as Belfast’s new Alliance Lord Mayor. The daughter of a Northern Ireland artist and a writer and ex-model from a family of anti-apartheid activists in South Africa, her story is extraordinary.“My mum and dad met at a house party in London in the s,” she says. “They were both hippies. My dad Kenneth was an artist from Holywood in Co Down. My mum, who was from Capetown, was working as a nanny.“They were both liberal and bohemian, and had found the places they’d grown up extremely restrictive. It was a whirlwind romance, but my mum Helen had to go back to South Africa as her visa was about to expire.“Back in Capetown, she wanted toto London. My grandparents, very sensibly, refused to fund a trip for their -year-old daughter to hook up with a man she’d just met. My mum had been an artists’ model and had sat for a well-known painter. She sold the portrait to buy a plane ticket to London to be with dad.”Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseKate Nicholl at school in Zimbabwe FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueKate Nicholl at school in ZimbabweThe couple got married and moved to Brighton. But, for some reason, they decided toto Northern Ireland where Kate’s brother Daniel and sister Ciara were born. Kenneth worked as an art teacher, and Helen secured a job in the children’s department of Robinson and Cleaver.“In  they decided they couldn’t stay here any longer,” Kate says. “The violence and sectarianism was too much. They didn’t want their children growing up in a segregated environment.“My dad started writing to dferent countries to see where he might get a job. Zimbabwe was this newly independent country that needed teachers. My parents were very excited about what Robert Mugabe stood for. It was also close to South Africa for my mum to visit her family.”The Nicholls moved to Harare before settling in the small farming town of Marondera. Kate was born there six years later. “It was a wonderful and magical childhood in so many ways,” she says.“My dad was the art teacher in the local school, and my mum the librarian. My parents were very creative and had interesting friends. There was a lot of sport — swimming and canoeing down the Zambezi.There was endless bushland to roam around. It was the most stunning landscape. I can still see the night sky with stars that seemed to go on forever. I can smell the sweet scent of the jacaranda trees in bloom.“But it was a strange environment as well. There was a lot of racism. It was very unusual for a white family like ours to have black friends. I was the only white child at school who had black classmates over to stay at the weekend. It was a totally unnatural society.”In South Africa, Kate’s grandmother had been in the Black Sash, an organisation of white women which campaigned against apartheid. They would wear black sashes to symbolise mourning for the death of democracy.Kate’s brother left Zimbabwe for university in Capetown, and her sister went to college in Belfast. Her parents’ marriage then broke up, and her father also ed to Northern Ireland.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseKate with husband Fergal Sherry FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueKate with husband Fergal Sherry“It was just me and mum left,” she says. “The political situation started to get really tense. White farmers were being abducted and beaten. David Stevens, the father of a school friend, was shot dead.There were food and fuel shortages, and riots.My mum drove to town to fill her car with petrol. She waited two hours in a queue but, when she got to the front, there was none left.“She came home to find the electricity was out in another power cut. In a dark, empty house, she reached for the phone, and the lines were down. So she got into bed with a bottle of gin and decided it was time for us to leave.”When her parents had arrived in Zimbabwe, it was “a country full of political hope”, Kate says. “As a child, I wrote in my diary that Robert Mugabe was my hero. As things deteriorated, I scribbled that out and replaced him with Nelson Mandela.“Mugabe did some incredible things, but there were a lot of awful things too. Land reform was definitely needed, but he didn’t go about it the right way.There was brutality and massacres. Elections were rigged and corruption was widespread.“Land seizures destroyed the economy. Middle-class whites like us left. It was poor black Zimbabweans who were hardest hit. This beautul country, and its long-suffering people, deserved so much better.”And so in , Kate and Helen Nicholl moved into their flat in Dunmurry. “My mother is an extraordinary woman,” she says. “At  years old, with no money, no job and no friends, she was starting all over again.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseKate with her son Cian FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueKate with her son Cian“Being a white African is textbook privilege. I grew up where people had horses and huge farms. But I do know what it’s like not to have money, and to worry about it. I know that le can change very quickly and you have to rely on the support and kindness of others, and being welcomed and embraced.”Kate was sent to the very middle-class Methodist College where family and financial circumstances combined to make her feel “like an outsider for years”. Eventually, she settled in.“My mum got a job in the War On Want bookshop in Botanic Avenue. It didn’t pay well, but she loved it. She built up a friendship circle with volunteers and customers. They became a second family to me.“We moved to Sunnyside Street, off the Ormeau Road, where a Georgian piano player lived next door. When she practised, we imagined ourselves to be sitting on the veranda in Marondera at dusk, listening to my sister play.”After her A-levels Kate moved in with her dad, who had cancer, to help nurse him. She then decided to go to university in London: “I still felt an outsider in Northern Ireland because of my background and accent, and I had every intention of never ing to live here again.“I decided to study anthropology because my favourite uncle in South Africa was an anthropologist, and he had the best stories. I thought I’d love London, but every time I came back to Northern Ireland to visit my family I realised that this place was home. Belfast was where I belonged.”After graduation Kate moved back here permanently. She started waitressing, and applied to do a law conversion course at Queen’s University. She also wrote to Alliance South Belfast MLA Anna Lo askingshe could do work experience in her office.Kate identied strongly with the politician from Hong Kong as someone like her who had come from abroad to make Northern Ireland her home: “She was the first person I voted for.“I respected her pro-choice stance on abortion at a time when not many people here held that position. Anna agreed to have me in for a day a week, and that turned into two days, and then it became the entire week.“A full-time job came up. I applied, got it, and forgot all about the law course. I never intended to join Alliance. I didn’t think I was suited to being a member of any political party as I was very much my own woman and I always thought it would limit me.“But the  flag protests changed my mind. They were a cynical and orchestrated move by loyalists, apparently in response to a democratic decision taken by the council, but really because Naomi Long had won the Westminster seat in East Belfast.“I saw Alliance’s office in Carrickfergus burnt down. I saw the home of a young councillor couple attacked as their baby slept inside. I decided to join the party to show solidarity with these brave and dignied people.”In  Kate was co-opted onto Belfast City Council. At the election three years later she topped the poll in the Balmoral ward. On a night out with an SDLP member in the Duke of York pub in Belfast city centre, she met her future husband, “GAA-mad accountant from Aghadrumsee in Co Fermanagh” Fergal Sherry.“I tapped this boy on the shoulder and asked him to take a photo of us on my phone. He did, and as he handed it back to me he remarked that we followed each other on Twitter. Apparently, we’d had quite a strong clash of opinion on something. We still have dferent views on certain issues, but we share similar values.“Fergal proposed in Zimbabwe in a small game reserve I’d visited on school trips. We were on top of a rock overlooking the savanna at sunset. It was perfect. I felt like I’d come full circle with my old and new lives.”The couple have a one-year-old son, Cian. “He’s had a political baptism of fire,” Kate says. “He attended his first council committee meeting at four weeks.He was breastfed in the chamber at seven weeks, and was in a BBC studio at eight weeks as we discussed the trolling I’d received for taking him into the chamber the previous week.”Kate has been chosen as a running-mate for Alliance MLA Paula Bradshaw in South Belfast in next year’s Assembly election.The party will be hoping that public exposure from being Lord Mayor will enhance her chances. It’s a fascinating constituency with the SDLP, Alliance, Sinn Fein, DUP and Greens currently each holding a seat.The SDLP will also be aiming to follow up on Claire Hanna’s spectacular Westminster win in  by having two MLAs elected. The Sinn Fein or Green seats would appear to be the most vulnerable.Kate says poverty is an issue high on her agenda. “It has grown during Covid, and there must be a long-term Government plan to tackle systemic injustice. It’s not just about handing out food parcels.If your washing-machine has broken, and your kids can’t go to school in clean clothes, a food parcel won’t help you. If you live in an empty house, it’s a bed and sofa you need, not a food parcel.“And no politician should ever have their photo taken outside a food bankthey’re not working to address the causes of inequality.”Kate says digital poverty is also an issue: “As we live more and more online, the internet should be free to everyone. Families don’t need one device per household.They need devices for all their children, they need money for electricity and data.”Her theme as Lord Mayor will be ‘Our Belfast’, she says: “We are one community and we have one city. We need to shine a light on its people and organisations, and instil a sense of collective responsibility.We must make sure the marginalised, and those who feel outsiders, know it’s their city too.For many people, Belfast is still steeped in the past and the Troubles. But for me, it’s a place of sanctuary.It’s somewhere I started my le over again. It’s a resilient, warm and welcoming city. I am delighted to call it my home, and I will be so proud to be its Lord Mayor.”Belfast Most ReadAdrian Dunbar and top Orangeman Mervyn Gibson split over Ireland in Sinn Fein ‘crushed our sister’: While working in the Prison Service he dealt with high-profile loyalists like Johnny Adair and Billy Wright. He then joined the fire service in , rising to the position of watch commander before leaving to become an MLA. The UUP MLA offered to temporarilyto the fire service last yearneeded during the coronavirus pandemic.Religious views: Mr Butler has described himself as a born-again Christian, having a strong faith and has served as a deacon at Maghaberry Elim Church.Political career: Mr Butler is viewed as one of the most capable young voices in unionism and has been earmarked as a future UUP leader. He said he was he was inspired to get involved in politics out of sheer frustration at seeing the lack of political leadership in our country.He was first elected to Lisburn City Council in , before being elected to Stormont at the same time as Mr Beattie in  to represent Lagan Valley. He has twice unsuccessfully run for Westminster in the  and  General Elections.Political views: The Lagan Valley MLA has said that he considers himself neither pro-le or pro-choice, but opposed the extension of abortion legislation to NI by the UK Government. He has also expressed concern around religious protections in the event of same-sex marriage becoming legal. In  he was criticised by the DUP for representing the UUP in Dublin at a civic reception during the visit of Pope Francis.Other information: Mr Butler and his we have acted as foster parents offering emergency and respite care to children in need. He has also served as a Boys# Brigade officer.Doug Beattie: Ardent critic of NI Protocol and supporter of LGBT community here Age:  Current positions: UUP deputy leader, Upper Bann MLA. Family: Married to Margaret with two children, daughter Leigh and son Luke. Background: Born in Hampshire, England, but moved to Portadown at age  after his father was discharged from the Army. Career: A soldier by trade, Mr Beattie signed up to the Army at the age of  and served in Bosnia, Kosovo, Iraq and Afghanistan during a decorated -year military career. He has written extensively about his experiences as a soldier in a number of books, in which he spoke openly about killing an enemy during combat. He was awarded the Military Cross in recognition of his efforts during his career. Religious views: Despite a Church of Ireland background, Mr Beattie has stated he has “issues with organised religion”, but does believe in God. He has spoken about struggling with his faith following his experiences in the Army and after the sudden death of his grandson Cameron at just  months old. Political career: After an initial reluctance, Mr Beattie was persuaded to enter politics by former UUP leader Mike Nesbitt. He was elected to Armagh, Banbridge and Craigavon council in  representing Portadown. In  he was elected MLA for Upper Bann. He also unsuccessfully ran to represent Upper Bann in the House of Commons in  and . Political views: Mr Beattie is one of the more liberal UUP MLAs. He has spoken out in support of Northern Ireland’s LGBT community, appearing at Belfast Pride. He also recently introduced a motion to the Assembly calling for a ban on conversion therapy. As the UUP’s justice spokesperson he has also spoken out on matters concerning his fellow military veterans, legacy issues and policing. Mr Beattie has also been an ardent critic of the post-Brexit Northern Ireland Protocol. A glistening picture of Kenny and Dean, grinning from ear to ear, with the Scottish League Cup after Kilmarnocks  success, sticks out from a row of framed mementos. There is no doubt this is a football house. Dean is now the manager of Dungannon Swts. His other son, Jody, manages the local cross community team Upperlands Aces where Kenny is the Chairman. googletag.cmd.push “It is only a title,” he admits. Football is in the blood. “I mark out the pitch, cut the grass...just trying to keep them going.” One of his daughters, Lauren, is married to Coleraine manager Oran Kearney. Armagh City manager Shea Campbell is married to Grace. His we Gwens brothers were footballers. You soon get the picture of the football discussion bouncing around the dinner table. On a Thursday afternoon, on the same day he signed a two-year extension to his contract as Northern Ireland womens manager, Shiels welcome is a warm one. He sips on a cuppa, relaxed, just shooting the breeze. Talking football comes naturally. googletag.cmd.push It was always football, even at the age of two. In hospital for a hernia operation, Kenny cried his eyes out. His mother, Elizabeth, tried to pacy him. But, it wasnt the pain, rather, someone had taken his ball. Once it was ed, the tears stopped. “It must be in my genes somewhere...I was football mad,” Kenny utters. He turned  weeks ago, but the glint remains in his eye. Before Covid- took hold, he was a regular at the nearby leisure centre. The mantra is early to bed, early to rise and practice what you preach. Another passion is music. Tucked in the corner of the kitchen is a record player, with a selection of LPs. Front of the pile is his favourite, John Prine.     “Music is just great,” Kenny offers, painting a picture of the power generated by Labi Sfres Something Inside So Strong. As the Northern Ireland team are about to leave their hotel, the words of the song set the scene. The song changes, depending on the atmosphere. The words and crescendo...they both matter. Shiels gained a degree in psychology along his footballing journey. As he speaks, he picks his words well. An hour in his company gives a taste of how Northern Ireland women, who went four years without a win, will mix with Europes elite next summer. *** Shiels first gig in management came in Beagh Primary School at the age of eight. The nearby, much bigger, Maghera County school came to play a friendly match. “Shiels...pick that team,” bellowed Principal Mr Gillen. “It was a hiding to nothing,” said Shiels of the game, in which he helped himself to five goals in an eight all draw. “There were no tactics,” Kenny laughs. “I got the ball and dribbled. They were trying to kick lumps out of me, but couldnt get near me.” Football was never away from the family home on a chicken farm on the outskirts of Maghera. Kenny was fourth of nine children, which included eight boys. Their father Roy had installed lights in the front yard. Every Saturday night, theyd re-emerge after Match of the Day, singing the tune as they raced outside, playing until after midnight. “My father was a Unionist Councillor...this town was polarised at one time,” Kenny points out. Roy Shiels was able to drink in any of the  pubs in Maghera. One of the few that could. “He got houses for everybody, no matter what creed they were...he was a very popular man.” With a deep interest in football, Roy formed a team comprising Catholics from the upper part of the town and Protestants from the bottom end. “He was bringing communities together to go and compete together in a sporting environment,” Kenny proudly states. “They came together and became friends to this day. Larry Cudden, who played for us, texted me a few minutes ago.” Roy took a cattle trailer, with the whole team in it and sometimes a couple in the boot of the car. It wouldnt conform with todays regulations. Roys Chicks, as they were called, hammered everyone in sight in tournaments across the North. After bagging seven goals in a game, Kenny was accused of being overage. The following year, the Chicks went international, on a five-day trip to France. Seamus Heffron, a French teacher on his year out, helped Roy organise the trip, which was funded by a raffle for a ball signed by the England and Spanish national teams. “Off they went to France, in the late seventies,” said Kenny, now too old to go. “Children got to Portrush for a weekend and that was it.” Kenny was football mad and sneaked away for a fleeting Gaelic football spell with Glen minors in , at the height of the troubles. On the Saturday evening hed leave a kitbag in a lane near his home. The following morning, his mother would have him kitted out in a shirt and tie for Sunday school. “I would change into my ordinary clothes and go on to a game,” he recalls. “Playing Gaelic, when I think back at the height of the troubles, I was mincemeat. Medical advice told him to hang up his boots, but he ploughed on. He went on to play for Distillery, Coleraine, Ballymena and Larne in the Irish league. ALLIANZ NHL DIVISION B Mayo -Derry - Derrys promotion hopes took a hit on Sunday in Castlebar after the Oakleafers went down to Mayo in Round  of the league. A storming finish, spearheaded by Niall Ferris goal, had Dominic McKinley and Cormac Donnellys side back in the game, but a late Brian Hunt insurance point sealed victory for the home side. Mayo had the use of the breeze in the first half and had the ball over the bar in the first minute from a Shane Boland free. Niall Ferris replied with a point, but Derry had a goal chance only for Brian Cassidys shot to come back off the post. googletag.cmd.push Derry lost Darragh Cartin to injury and it was Mayo who went into a - to - lead with points from captain Keith Higgins and Adrian Philips. Mayo totted up  wides in the first half, but with long-range efforts from Sean Regan and Cathal Freeman, Mayo led - to - after  minutes. Derry stayed in touch with ODoherty frees before Boland nailed a fourth free to open up a - to - lead for the home side at the break. ODoherty had the ball over the bar seconds after the restart, followed by two frees, giving wind-assisted Derry a positive start to the second half. googletag.cmd.push Shane Boland and Sean Regan replied to keep Mayo in front, - to -, after  minutes. A Keith Higgins point put Mayo five clear before Brian Cassidy replied for Derry. Freeman, Boland and Keith Higgins added points from the home side, who went into a - to -. Just when the game was going away from them, Niall Ferris found the net to give Derry a leline after  minutes. ODoherty, from a  and Brian Cassidy tagged on points as Derry narrowed the gap to a point before Shane Boland fired over an inspirational score from close to the sideline.     Derry needed a goal in stoppage time and after a high ball into the Mayo square, Gerard Bradley fired over the bar. It was Mayo who finished strong. Keith Higgins was involved in the move for Brian Hunts insurance point. In the other game in Division B, Ronan McDermott scored a late goal as Donegal were - to - winners over Roscommon in Letterkenny. Next Saturday, Roscommon host Mayo in Round , with Kildare at home to Donegal. Derrys have a bye next week, but play Christy Ring Champions Kildare on Sunday, May  at .pm. In Division , Antrim were - to - winners over Clare at Corrigan Park, but Down lost to Kerry - to - on theirto Division A in Tralee. Deputy chief medical officer Dr Ronan Glynn has said Donegal will move out of Level  public health restrictions along with the rest of the Republic on Monday amid concerns about the high levels of Covid- in the county. Dr Glynn said he is hopeful that additional measures will not be required for the county in the coming weeks and he is confident that the situation in Donegal will improve quickly. He was speaking at a press briefing for the media in Donegal on Wednesday following the fallout from comments made by chief medical officer Dr Tony Holohan last Friday about the high incidence of Covid- in the county. googletag.cmd.push There has been a backlash in Donegal to the tone of the comments Dr Holohan made when he said there were concerns about things happening in the county that “even the dogs on the street” know shouldn’t be happening. Figures released at the press briefing put the national incidence rate in the county at  cases per , people compared to a national rate of . The highest rates are in the Milford local electoral area at . and the Letterkenny area where the rate is .. The lowest rate in the county is in the Donegal LEA at .. The briefing was told there were  GP referrals for testing in the county on Tuesday, an increase of % on the same day last week. googletag.cmd.push Dr Glynn said the concerns were raised last week so that people can take protective measures and ensure the situation does not get worse. He said there is a bigger number of smaller clusters in Donegal than in other parts of the country. “It was not meant as blame. It certainly was not made as a threat,” he said. “It would be very strange for us to preside over a situation where incidence is very high and increasing in a county and not draw attention to that.” At the briefing, director of public health for the HSE in the north-west, Dr Anthony Breslin, highlighted a number of clusters that have occurred due to events in the county in recent weeks, including awake, a family gathering and an th birthday party.     The events resulted in dozens of cases and infections in workplaces, in families and at a school. One social gathering has been linked to  cases of Covid-, he said. Dr Glynn said that there are concerns about the situation in the county and that some people in Donegal have “pushed the boundaries”. “We are concerned about the current incidence. That is not to say that Donegal has not come a very long way over the past number of months, just as the rest of the country has, and that can only have happened because the majority of people are trying to do the right thing,” he said. “This is not in any way a reflection on the majority but clearly there are a number of incidents where people have pushed the boundaries. “We have seen that in other counties, it is not just in Donegal. But I suppose the dference at the moment versus some other places where we have particularly high incidences, is that there are large clusters driving incidences. “In Donegal, it seems to be a little bit more widespread with a bigger number of smaller clusters which makes it that little bit harder to control. Sowe can continue to emphasise, andwe can get people who have been pushing the boundaries a little bit just to comply that bit more over the coming weeks, we should see incidence drop quickly in Donegal.” He said we can not get away from the fact that the high incidence rates in parts of the county are due to the fact the disease is being transmitted from person to person. “It gets transmitted from person to person when people come into contact with one another and when for whatever reason masks are not worn, distance is not kept, people who are symptomatic don’t self-isolate. “Right now we are seeing a higher incidence in Donegal than we have in other parts of the country and in that regard, it is incumbent on us as doctors to point out our concerns so that people can take proactive actions because there are many people who remain very vulnerable to this disease over the coming weeks,” he said. “All we are asking people in Donegal to do is to protect themselves and their families. We are not proposing any dferent measures for any one part of Donegal as things currently stand, and I would be hopeful and optimistic given the level of engagement over the past number of days that we wont be looking at some sort of additional measures for the county or any part of the county over the coming weeks.” He said the priority for people over the coming weeks is to meet people outside. “As far as is possible at all, do not meet up with friends or extended families or do not have parties inside. Inside gives this virus such an advantage in terms of transmission,” he said. “Last January Donegal had an incidence of , per ,. It is now  per ,. It is the highest in the country but it’s an order of magnitude lower than where it was and that’s down to the work of the majority doing most of the right things most of the time.”  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. One of the most prominent locations in Derrys city centre is set for a new lease of le. The buildings at  and  Strand Road have been empty since a Boojum restaurant closed last March. Now, as business le in the city slowly restarts after the devastating impact of the pandemic, it has emerged that a new coffee house is to open in the Strand Road buildings which lie at the busy junction with Clarendon Street. Final preparations are being made for the opening of the Industry Deli  Coffee House. The owners of the business say it will be opening soon. googletag.cmd.push This will be seen as a huge boost for business le in the Strand Road area. Before Boojum, the Sandwich Company occupied the Strand Road building for many years. As business le in the city centre slowly s, Brian Tierney, Mayor of Derry City and Strabane District Council, has been visiting local shops to offer the councils support. He urged people to shop local as much as possible. I was glad to meet with some of the local businesses across our district this week and hear more about the positive steps forward now that many of those businesses have reopened or are preparing for a scheduled reopening in the coming weeks. googletag.cmd.push It was fantastic to see lots of people supporting those businesses while I was out and about and to see that all of the businesses have measures in place to instill confidence in all members of the public that they can support local and be assured that everything is in place to protect both themselves and staff. I can fully appreciate how much of a challenge the past year has been for our businesses across a wide range of sectors, and I look forward to the weeks ahead when we hope to see more of those sectors reopening and ing to a more normal operation of business,” said the Mayor.     Once again I would just like to encourage everyone to support local across the district as much as you can.  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. A Derry woman inspired by the events of Bloody Sunday to become involved in politics has been elected to represent the Labour Party on an English council. Mairead Healy, who is originally from Meenan Park in the Bogside area, was successful in last Thursdays council election in Romsey, a town with a population of around , people which is located seven miles from Southampton in the south of England. Speaking after her success, she said her thoughts were with her late mother Frances, brother and grandmother. She said: “I am over the moon that the people of Romsey have placed their trust in me to represent them for the Labour Party. googletag.cmd.push “As most people who know me will know, I’m not there simply to make up the numbers and I’m looking forward to rolling up my sleeves and getting stuck in - and maybe shaking things up a bit too.” She added: “For now, feeling so incredibly blessed and grateful to so many people who believed in me and who got out on the streets in the hail, wind and rain to canvas for me and the rest of the Romsey candidates. Thank you. “I’m also thinking about my mum, my wee brother Eamonn and my granny. It’s days like these when you really feel their absence, as they have missed out on so many of me and my sister Orla Oacute hEacuteiliacute’s big le events. googletag.cmd.push “But I’ve no doubt they have been watching over us from heaven and helping us along the way from up above.” Mairead left Derry  years ago to study law in the UK and has held several important positions, starting off her career working for the European Commission in Brussels. She then worked in human rights in London before making a career change and moving to Dublin to lead a national youth charity for several years. After that, she moved to the south of England where she was chief executive of a youth mental health service and was appointed to the Youth Justice Board for England and Wales, a role she has recently stepped down from.     Currently, she works for a major international human rights organisation where she is part of the leadership team. She is also a postgrad student at Cambridge, training to be a child therapist and is head of safeguarding with Amnesty International UK, a post she has held since September . She said being brought up in Derry during The Troubles and the events of Bloody Sunday inspired her to get involved in struggles for justice and become an advocate for those without a voice. She said: “Growing up in the ’s as a working class Catholic from the Bogside during The Troubles in Northern Ireland, I was very much aware of the civil rights struggle affecting my community, particularly as the events of Bloody Sunday took place just a few streets from my home, where civil rights demonstrators were murdered by the British army. “As a result, it instilled in me from a young age a strong desire to be involved in struggles for justice and advocating for those without a voice. “In addition, as an adult, I also experienced some le changing events through the loss of some of my close family members in traumatic circumstances, which also affected my decision to campaign on particular areas of inequality.” She added she was really privileged to be able to work with and volunteer with ious communities over the years including Traveller groups, survivors of institutional abuse, refugees, iniduals who, she said, were homeless, young people and iniduals whose human rights are denied to them. She added: “As a result, I strongly believe in the value of grassroots capacity building to ensure that those without a voice can be supported to advocate for themselves and ensure their voices are heard and represented in decision making.” She explained her reasons for standing for election. “It goes without saying that the implications of the pandemic will be felt for many years to come and there will be signicant economic consequences of this, combined with Brexit. “I want to play my part in ensuring our communities are supported in the years ahead, which is why I am putting myself forward as a candidate.”   --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. A banner was unveiled at Free Derry Corner this evening in support of a campaign to have a detox centre opened in the city. The campaign is being led by local teenager Tamzin White whose mother, Louise, died earlier this year as a result of alochol addiction at the age of only . Other members of Tamzins family have also died from addiction. In honour of them, eighteen-year-old Tamzin has launched the campaign for the creation of a local detox centre to help those fighting addictions. Speaking at the unveiling of the new banner this evening, Tamzin she had been overwhelmed by the support she has received. googletag.cmd.push She said she would keep pushing until a new detox centre was opened in the city. Two County Derry teenagers have made a heartfelt plea for people to talk about suicide in men to mark the th anniversary of their fathers death. Eaacutebha Mullanand Ciaroacuten Mullan , from Ballerin, have written about the loss of their father Kieran Squealer Mullan in , when the siblings were just five and three years old. Ahead of a k sponsored run this weekend in aid of the Mental Health Awareness charity, Eaacutebha and Ciaroacutens mother, Collette, has shared her childrens plea to break the taboo around mens mental health. “On May  , it will be  years since Ciaroacuten and I last saw our Daddy. With cold shock, I realise that means hes been gone for  years longer than I knew him,” wrote Eaacutebha. googletag.cmd.push “We were only five and three when he took his own le. For many people, a period of time relieves much of the pain, and makes it easier to move on. “But for us, in many ways, its got worse. Losing a parent at five and three meant we didnt really understand death. I didnt even know it was suicide until I was in P. “Our Daddys death has left us with years of unsolved questions, new and fresh situations to face without a father. “Even from the day he died, we are still finding out new things about him to add to the tiny memories we thankfully have. Five years is no time to know someone well. googletag.cmd.push “I wish we could go back to those days when we were just a little boy and girl, too young to notice how down our Daddy really was. Eaacutebha has posted details of the sponsored runs route on social media. “I wish we could spread them throughout the rest of our lives knowing what people are thinking and going through, hoping we could help them in any possible way. “Why cant we swap the day he held us as a baby at our Christening, so he could watch us play Gaelic, win big matches and watch us succeed in le  “Ten years on and we are still listening to his favourite songs, watching the one existing video of him to remember his voice, crying on Fathers Day or his birthday, or any random day.     “We still cant let our Daddy go. Everyone thinks we might have moved on, because it happened such a long time ago. “But they dont know how it feels to look at the same few photographs, knowing there will never be any more. “They dont know how strange it feels to think we once had two parents. They dont know what its like to sit and talk to your Daddy at a gravestone at  and  knowing that he didnt want to be here. “If we let him go, hes gone forever, and we cant take that. The effect of suicide isnt just the loss of the person who left you behind, its the shadow always at your heel.” Eaacutebha and Ciaroacuten have shared their story in the hope it will help others to speak out about their mental health. “Ten years on, and suicide is still the leading cause of death for men under ,” said Eaacutebha. “Every day, men who feel like our Daddy did bottle up their feelings, try to appear strong, and drive themselves further into darkness. “Every day,  of them take their lives, leaving people like Ciaroacuten and I lost and heartbroken. And every day, we wish we could change what happened. “For our Daddy, the sun will never come out again, but the more we talk about it, the more we listen, the more others will live to see another day and the more the shadows will fade.”] The k sponsored run in memory of Kieran Squealer Mullan will take place on Sunday May , with all proceeds going to the Mental Health Awareness charity. A County Derry school girl has appeared in a two-part BBC drama. Brooke McEldowney, a Primary One pupil at St Brigids Tirkane Bunscoil Naomh Briacuted, has appeared in Three Families, part one of which aired last night. Three Families explores the emotive issues around womens rights and tells the story of the grassroots campaign to lt Northern Irelands restrictions on abortion. Brooke enjoying herself on set. Brooke landed the role after her mum Kirsty received an email from a casting agency. “When I opened an email about NI filming and how they were on the lookout for a young child, Brooke fitted the description,” she told Derry Now. googletag.cmd.push “It was all very overwhelming as the world was going through a pandemic and my daughter was now going to be part of a cast. It all felt like a dream.” For Brooke, the dream was very much a reality, and although she began filming at just four years of age, the young County Derry girl made light of the heavy schedule.  “She has been such a busy girl, taking everything in her stride and having so many dferent roles in filming and completely loving it all,” said Kirsty. “During the lockdowns while everyone was at home, I was arranging my other kids childcare and driving to our next destination for long days ahead. googletag.cmd.push “She had attended local drama and dance classes for a short while - pre-Covid - so this helped. She loved all the attention and getting chauffeured to each set, a few places I never expected to be.” Five-year-old Brooke has a central role in the drama as the daughter of actor Colin Morgan, previously of The Fall and actress Amy James Kelly, who has previously featured in Coronation Street. “When I met them and signed the contracts I knew that this was a big deal and how I had to keep everything a secret,” said Kirsty. “I had to travel myself to each set every couple of days prior filming to get a Covid test. Thankfully, they were all negative so Brooke could always continue with her role.”     The future is already looking bright for the Maghera girl, and she was handed a unique birthday present in February when she began filming on a CBBC musical drama series. “It was so perfect and fitting on her th birthday and the cast, producers and directors spoiled her,” said Kirsty. “Her confidence rapidly grew and has been even given spoken lines for on screen. She has gained multiple jobs since and has now been signed up by an agency.” Brooke on set with Colin Morgan and Amy James Kelly. Keeping her feet on the ground amid the excitement of her new-found fame will be an easy task with the support of her community and her school. “When ing to school after lockdown Brooke had days off due to filming but the BBC always liaised so well with the school,” said Kirsty. “Brooke is a very independent, intelligent girl and likes a good routine. She was thrilled when her teacher, Mrs Convery sent work via Seesaw and was always keen to get the tasks completed. “We are so proud and it has been an emotional journey as I have been involved in the Arts for many years and know how challenging it can be. “It’s all such an amazing experience and the opportunities it has opened for her have been remarkable. I am so privileged that we get to go on this journey together as mother and daughter. “We are bursting with pride.” Three Families is available to watch on BBC iPlayer, with the second part of the drama also airing tonight on BBC One at .pm.  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Derry will get their season off the ground on Sunday at Pearse Park, but they have always found Longford a tough nut to crack in the past. Of the eight meetings since the turn of the millennium, Derry have only won three of them, including last years clash under Rory Gallagher.  Qualiers RDerry - Longford -It took Derry a while to get going, but a devastating  minutes of football demolished the home side at Pearse Park. Derry were fortunate to be just three points down at the break, with the move of Enda Muldoon to midfield before half time turning the game. googletag.cmd.push Anthony Tohill, who scored two goals, was the major beneficiary of Muldoons sublime long passing. Qualiers RLongford - Derry -Longford earned a dramatic win in a chaotic finish at Pearse Park. There was controversy too. Derrys Barry McGoldrick, who had marauded forward from corner-back to grab two goals, picked up a second yellow card after a melee in the Longford goalmouth in the th minute of injury time. Minutes later, Derry sub Joe Diver scored a goal reminiscent of Joe Sheridans against Louth two previously - this time referee Michael Duffy awarded a free out and Longford were safe. Longford had led by three at the break, - to -, thanks largely to the accuracy from frees of Sean McCormack. Paddy Bradley showed all his class too in the opening phase of the game and was at the heart of anything productive from Derry. McGoldricks first goal levelled the match, finishing coolly, after being set up by Paddy Bradley. His second goal put Derry in the driving seat, despite not playing well. title: Bertie Ahern criticises PM and Taoiseach in St Patrick’s Podcast
story: FORMER Taoiseach Bertie Ahern has criticised the British and Irish Prime Ministers for failing to meet formally as required under the Good Friday Agreement.Mr Ahern, speaking on St Patrickrsquos Podcast, for the St Patrick Centre in Downpatrick, said that Micheaacutel Martin and Boris Johnson were obliged to have regular meetings of the British Irish Intergovernmental Conferenceand suggested ldquotalking to each other was not enough.He rejected their response to his previous criticism on the matter.ldquoBoth of them said they had been talking. Thatrsquos not the same as having a formal British Irish Intergovernmental Conference with officials and an agenda, he said.ldquoI have no objectionthey want to talk every day. Thatrsquos a good idea, but I think the institutions of the Good Friday Agreement should be followed and that means there should be a BIIC on a regular and frequent basis. That is what was signed.Speaking weeks after street violence by loyalist protesters erupted in Belfast over issues related to Brexit and the NI Protocol, Mr Ahern said BIIC meetings were very important.ldquoIt does concern me that we havenrsquot had a British Irish Intergovernmental Conference for a long, long time, maybe a few years.Mr Ahern was interviewed by former BBC political correspondent Martina Purdy and former barrister Elaine Kelly, who spoke to the former Taoiseach about peace-building, faith and St Patrick.ldquoThe two governments, the British and Irish governments are the custodians of the Agreement. They are not meeting to discuss these issues. That clearly is not in line with the agreement.ldquoI am not using any other words than what the Agreement usedhellip The agreement says that there must be frequent meetings and you know that should be happening.ldquoThey donrsquot have to be for long. They can be on zoom, Microsoft teams anything you like. They should be having these meetings and where there are dficulties they should be dealing with at those meetings.ldquoIn the absence of those meetings, things can drt. Quite frankly I donrsquot understand why those meetings canrsquot take place.ldquoI donrsquot expect the British Prime Minister and the Taoiseach to have a meeting all day ndash they donrsquot have to do that. They could have a meeting for an hour and half. Thatrsquos not going to kill anybody.He said other officials or ministers or institutions within departmental structures could then follow through with the issues.Mr Ahern also spoke about the future of the Catholic Church in Ireland, where he said there must be more involvement of the laity.He said his faith was important to him. ldquoYou donrsquot want to overplay it because you are attacked nowyou do that.ldquoReligion is important to me. I am a believer and I understand it and I read about it and I think itrsquos part of my le and I often think that a lot of people, who have a lot of problems and dficulties - it is because they donrsquot have it. All I can do is pray for them.During lockdown Mr Ahern shared how he went to mass regularly from his kitchen in Drumcondra, sharing masses online from Clonard monastery in Belfast, as well as Derry, Cork and Dublin.He said lockdown had given people time to reflect and enjoy walking, something he really enjoys.He told the podcasters mdash former Sisters of Adoration who are now pilgrim guides on Saint Patrickrsquos Way Downpatrick mdash that ldquohe would love to come and walk the Irish Camino with them.He revealed he had spent nine months of the lockdown reading The Annals of the Four Masters, chronicles of medieval Irish history.Mr Ahern described it as a ldquotough read, admitting he could only manage  pages a day.Asked what he would like to banish from Ireland, in the Spirit of St Patrick, he said ldquoinjustice and violence..prettyPhoto

title: Breastfeeding is the most beautiful thing
story: WHEN Joanne Masseyrsquos second child, Edward, was born six months ago, she knew she wanted to breastfeed him, but also,possible, donate to the milk bank.Weighing in at just over lbs, Edward fed for  minutes soon after he was born and it seemed like establishing feeding would be no problem.However, a few months before Edward was born, Joannersquos family found out her father, Jim Watson, had cancer.She explained: ldquoEventually we would learn it was terminal. So my stress levels were abnormally high.ldquoI soon felt like I couldnrsquot feed Edward enough, stress got the better of me at times and my brilliant health visitor Maura pointed me to a local breastfeeding group and also another brilliant lady, my breastfeeding peer support worker Aine Jordan-Doxey, who just completely gave me the confidence and support to keep going.ldquoThe peer breastfeeding group is hosted by a midwe health visitor and contains a beautul bunch of souls who are just there for each other. Wersquore all in the same boat and through this group I have received many tips, tricks and even friends.Despite Joannersquos determination to breastfeed Edward, it wasnrsquot all plain sailing.ldquoBreastfeeding is just the most beautul thing.Yes it can be dficult and absolutely frustrating at times but the benefits far outweigh those short blips, she said.ldquoThe best advice Irsquove ever heard mdash lsquodonrsquot give up on a bad dayrsquo.On a rough day, breastfeeding Edward gave me comfort, knowing I was the reason he is full and happy made me feel so good.ldquoAine gave me so much advice, including certain foods to eat to boost milk supply. Oats, theyrsquore your best friend! And you cannot drink enough water.Soon Joanne had more milk that Edward could take so she began collecting extra milk for the milk bank.She said: ldquoThe bottles arrived and I filled the first ml on December  last year. The donation was nearly full in a month but sadly my dad passed away on January  at the age of . There was a few weeks with no donations as my milk supply ped to an all-time low. Itrsquos just incredible what stress can do to your body.ldquoWell, Aine was there again, checking in, keeping me in chat, and keeping me motivated to keep breastfeeding. I am very lucky to have a wonderful, supportive husband, a close knit family and a close circle of best friends who have been tremendous during this very dficult time.Joanne went on to complete her donation of four litres of milk she calls ldquoliquid gold on Motherrsquos Day and wants to thank Aine for all her help and support.She said: ldquoI fully support every motherrsquos choice to either breastfeed or bottle-feed butanyone was struggling to breastfeed I would strongly recommend taking the support thatrsquos available.ldquoPersonally I am continuing to breastfeed because it gives me a little comfort in this time of grief, itrsquos a moment where I just look into his eyes and feel so needed and loved. So not only for the instantly available nutrition and comfort to my son but for those moments of joy I get from it too.Aine says she is so proud of Joanne mdash not only for continuing to breastfeed during the emotional time of her fatherrsquos illness and death but also for contributing four litres of milk to the Trustrsquos milk bank.The mother-of-threersquos own experience of breastfeeding had been rewarding but also not without its challenges.While she was living in England at the time, she recalled a time when one of her children was not thriving while she was feeding them.ldquoMy doctor and my health visitor both told me to stop breastfeeding my son and it was so frustrating as I knew that was not the problem so I continued on and it turned out that there was something  wrong.She began supporting Joanne in November last year when Edward was five weeks old.ldquoJoanne was exhausted and had been through some dficult nights where Edward wasnrsquot sleeping and was screaming through the night.I remember speaking with her about developmental leaps and what to expect at this stage and the normal infant sleep patterns, said Aine.ldquoFrom the beginning I could tell Joanne had so much passion for breastfeeding and wanted to succeed in every way. Joanne began expressing enough to give Edward a bottle and soon after he started sleeping better, just in time for her toddler to stop sleeping through. Joanne never let this stop her and carried on with minimal sleep.Aine said that when Joanne first mentioned to her about the possibility of donating milk, there were only  donors on the Northern Ireland milk bank.She said ldquoI was so proud as Joanne was the first of my mums to donate and it honestly made me smile at the thought. As usual Joanne just laughed and said it was no big deal as she enjoyed it. It was the first time I disagreed with her as I thought she was doing an extraordinary thing.ldquoWhen I opened her message and saw Edward surrounded by four litres of expressed milk for the milk bank, I was blown away again. What an incredible gt for the sick babies in theneonatal units.ldquoNot only was Joanne potty training a toddler and breastfeeding on demand, but she was expressing for the milk bank. I am so thankful to have been a part of her journey. So often there isnrsquot enough support available for mums especially with breastfeeding, and Covid made it more dficult as the usual support groups had all closed. Thatrsquos why peer support is so valuable as it provides one to one support for mums at the most important time.Aine highlighted the need for support for breastfeeding mums. ldquoWe need to be offering all mums support from the very first chance which is the case for a lot, but sometimes mums donrsquot know about us until itrsquos too late. ldquoI am thankful to Joanne for sharing this experience with me and I know we will still be in touch for a long time.ldquoAnd even though Irsquom sure she will downplay what she has achieved, I can honestly say I am so proud of her and all her hard work.Mothers can be referred to the Trustrsquos breastfeeding support worker through midwery and health visiting services..prettyPhoto

title: Carlisle’s staff in charity hike in memory of much loved Pat
story: ONE hundred staff and friends at Carlislersquos in Ballynahinch are each walking five miles this week on a sponsored walk in honour of a much-loved colleague who died last month.Pat Greene, who was from Saintfield, died on April , much to the shock and sorrow of everyone at the business.The  year-old had worked for Carlislersquos for  years, starting off as a coal boy, going on to work in all areas of the business and finishing as a work supervisor.Donna Carlisle explained that Pat loved The Proclaimers song Irsquom Gonna Beand it inspired the charity effort from staff members, past and present, and their partners.ldquoIt was Patrsquos favourite song and it had to be on the playlist at all our party nights when we raised money for ious cancer charities. Raising money for these charities was always important to Patrick as his mother sadly passed away from the disease when he was young, she said.ldquoHe never missed any of the parties and when The Proclaimers came on I always remember Pat taking centre stage and all of us had to follow him and his actions and it was always very important we did it right.ldquoThis is one memory of Pat we will never forget. We think it is very fitting that between us all we will walk those  miles for our friend and colleague whilst raising much needed funds for Cancer Focus NI in his name.The walkers aim to complete the  miles by Sunday, having started last Sunday.Mrs Carlisle praised her late colleague as a person who was ldquouniversally liked.ldquoI honestly never heard one bad word said about Pat. He was just one of those members of staff you just loved to have around you, she said. ldquoHe was brilliant, did anything and always tried to keep everyone right. He was always there and became part of the furniture, as they say.ldquoHe really became a friend over the years and he will be sorely missed by us all.Money will be raised through staff sponsorship and JustGiving donation on Carlislersquos Facebook page. Contributions can also be left into the Belfast Road shop in Ballynahinch.Carlislersquos Fuels have donated  litres of oil while Carlislersquos Food SuperValu is donating pound worth shopping vouchers for a prize draw for everyone who donates.The draw will take place on Monday, May , and winners will be contacted by Facebook page or telephone. To donate visit www.justgiving fundraising paddyswalkmiles.prettyPhoto

title: Cheers – pubs reopen
story: LOCAL beer gardens and restaurants welcomed ato business as Covid restrictions were eased last Friday.Downpatrick-based Murphyrsquos Bar and Restaurant, Denvirrsquos Coaching Inn, Turleyrsquos Bar and the Mirabelle Bar and Killough based Anchor Bar were among the public houses that reopened their doors to eager members of the public.Despite some guidelines still being in place such as track and trace and limiting the amount of households at one table together, that didnrsquot dampen the spirits of the members of the public who made full use of their favourite locals serving again.Mark Murphy, co-owner of Murphyrsquos, said he was delighted at being able to welcome back familiar faces to his premises whilst sharing a laugh or two with them throughout the day.ldquoItrsquos great. Finally after a long layoff we can resume a bit of normality in our outdoor beer garden, Mr Murphy said. ldquoWe have installed a new bar outside to coincide with the rules that are still in place and we have enjoyed creating a new look premises for the locals to enjoy, he continued.ldquoWe have missed many things but none more so than our loyal customers.Whilst soaking in the busy atmosphere, customer Sarah Taggart said: ldquoItrsquos been a long five months, I have missed the craic and seeing the dferent people around the bar. It is great to be back.Denvirrsquos also enjoyed greeting their customers, who enjoyed a meal and drinks in the beer garden.Co-owner Chris Dagens said: ldquoAfter a long time away, we can finally see our customers again. Itrsquos fantastic to see so many familiar people who we have greatly missed and long may it continue.The establishment has also been using the lsquoB expressrsquo mobile app in the beer garden so customers can order from their table and reduce further contact.ldquoThe app is great, itrsquos convenient for customers and makes it so much easier to get their orders to their tables at the fastest time. We have had great feedback on it so far and we will continue to use it, he added.Turleyrsquos have recently installed an outdoor beer garden right on time for reopening. Using the duration away from regular opening hours to his advantage, owner Kieran Turley has expanded his premises.ldquoTo reopen the doors again has been a relief. We started to expand when things were going downhill for the hospitality business and have really made use of the layoff, he said.ldquoI love seeing customers back at the bar, evenit is outdoors. The main thing is that my customers will be able to safely enjoy ato the bar, he added.Customer Siobhan Botsford said: ldquoKieran is a great host. He has taken care of us all throughout lockdown and really cares for his customers. My friends and I are regulars here because of how he treats us all.At the Mirabelle Bar in Market Street, owner Ann Blackwood was optimistic as she expressed her happiness at being allowed to invite members of the public back to their local.ldquoItrsquos so good to be back, we havenrsquot opened since October, she said.ldquoItrsquos great to see the town busy again, the shops are back open but most importantly so are the bars and hairdressers.Customer Roberta Marie McCoubrey said: ldquoIrsquom glad to be back at the bar with all my friends. Itrsquos great seeing everyone out enjoying themselves, we all deserve it.Meanwhile in Killough, the Anchor Bar have began serving the locals their favourite selection of beers, all whilst supplying sports entertainment on their outdoor television.Owner John Fitzsimmons said: ldquoIt feels absolutely brilliant to be back in action. I have missed all of the regulars so much throughout lockdown. Thankfully, it looks as though therersquos light at the end of the tunnel and we are doing everything we can to ensure a safeto all the customers.Among those enjoying the reopening was Cora Kelly, who said: ldquoItrsquos great to finally get back to a sense of normality. John has been so great throughout lockdown supplying an off-sales for the village and he always make an effort to make everyone feel as comfortable as he can when we are all here..prettyPhoto

title: Chefs cook up a treat on Great British Menu
story: TWO local chefs flew the flag with top class cuisine in last weekrsquos Northern Ireland regional heat of Great British Menu.Carryduff chef Gemma Austin mdash who is a former student of Assumption Grammar School in Ballynahinch mdash was beaten in Fridayrsquos nightrsquos decider of the BBC Two show by Londonderry chef Phelim OrsquoHagan, who will go on to represent Northern Ireland in the grand final.It was the first entry for the  year-old who is chef and co-owner of Alexanders in Holywood.Paul Cunningham, chef owner of Brunels in Newcastle, was invited back to compete in this yearrsquos competition after impressing judges last year. However, he did not make it through to show his impressive main course and dessert to the judges.Both chefs threw their all into devising four courses, including an appetiser and pre-dessert mdash based on the theme celebrating British innovation.Hopes were high for East Down given that Dundrum chef Alex Browne Greene, from EIPIC restaurant in Belfast, got two dishes to the national final last year and narrowly missed out on being crowned champion of champions at the banquet.Gemmarsquos starter was a twist on gammon, egg and chips, inspired by Kegomatic from Queenrsquos University students and for her fish course, the innovation shown in the building of the Titanic inspired her sea bass fish dish.She used William Clannyrsquos invention of the safety lamp for miners for her main course of lamb and the influence of astronomer Alice Everett as the first woman to work for the Royal Observatory to inspire her dessert, Out of this World.The dessert was her favourite course and she was delighted to have been scored a ten by chef Daniel Clford.ldquoIrsquom known for my desserts so I was really delighted to have got that score from Daniel, said Gemma.ldquoI also took his advice on my main course as therersquos no better person to take advice from and generally scaled back my dishes and made them more refined as the comments back were that there was too much on the plate.While Gemma was proud to have made it through to the regional final, she said she was not disappointed at not going through to the national judging.ldquoTo be honest, it was a bit of a relief as I did not know how I was going to go up against all the other chefs in the national final as I have only been cheffing for seven years and am mostly self-taught, she revealed.Gemma went into the competition, which was filmed last November, full of confidence and determined to do her best.ldquoI think I just went into a zone and concentrated on my own dishes and not to get too caught up in what the other chefs were doing, she said.ldquoPhelim was brilliant on the day and deserved to win and I remember saying on the programme that the better chef won. I hope that he goes on to get a dish to the banquet.While she has been receiving fantastic customer feedback from her popup, A Peculiar Tea, which she has been operating during the lockdowns, Gemma admitted that cooking was not her first career choice.ldquoWhen I left school I actually went to Queenrsquos University to do a nursing degree but a medical issue I experienced meant that I couldnrsquot complete it, she said.She then studied Bio Medical Sciences for a while before going to Ulster University to complete a software engineering degree.Her love of food and cooking mdash inspired by her chef mother mdash was strictly a hobby until the age of  when she took her first job at Slims Kitchen on the Lisburn Road in Belfast where she cut her teeth for a year while doing a Culinary Masters course.For four years Gemma continued studying and working full-time at a iety of great establishments, such as the Fitzwilliam Hotel in Belfast where she rose to head pastry chef, before moving The Old Inn, Crawfordsburn, where she worked all the sections and eventually became sous chef.She has been in Alexanders for the last two years and got the opportunity to become an owner last year.ldquoIt may have taken my several attempts before I found the right career but I was determined not to do any job that I did not absolutely love and was passionate about.Like Gemma, Brunels chef Paul Cunningham hopes to be invited back next year after his disappointing showing this year.The  year-old had hoped to get to the regional judging to please his six-year-old daughter, Farrah.ldquoFarrah and I are massive fans of the show, we watch every year and of course, I wanted to further than I did but Irsquove got over the disappointment now and concentrating on getting the restaurant ready for re-opening, Paul told the Recorder.Paul is known for only using local produce from within a -mile radius of Newcastle and foraging for herbs and plants.His menu reflected his locality and passion for pioneers including Belfast-born Dame Jocelyn Bell Burnell and Isambard Kingdom Brunelrsquos refloating of the SS Great Britain in Dundrum Bay mdash an incident which led him to name his restaurant by the great engineer.Paul only got to cook his starter and main course on the show but said his main course and dessert were showstoppers, with the main course of lamb called Healthy Heart made without using any salt or butter, inspired by Frank Pantridge who invited the portable defibrillator.He also collaborated with Doran Precision Engineering to create a model of the Titanic for one of his dishes and a special dish to show off his dessert, the Atom Smasher, inspired by Dame Jocelyn Bell Burnell..prettyPhoto

title: Condemnation over Murlough vandalism
story: LOCAL politicians have criticised vandals responsible for setting fire to a gate at the Murlough Nature Reserve two weekends ago as  firefighters were battling a huge blaze in the nearby Mournes.The vandals also left behind a trail of rubbish at the internationally acclaimed area with their actions condemned by South Down MLA Colin McGrath and Mournes councillor Laura Devlin.They say it ldquobeggars belief that while the raging wildfire destroyed  acres of rich habitat across the Mournes, there were people who thought that it was appropriate to start a fire at the Nature Reserve.The politicians also revealed that National Trust staff had to remove  bags of rubbish from the Reserve location on the Sunday the fire in the Mournes was eventually extinguished.Cllr Devlin said as young people drank alcohol and watched the blaze raging across the mountains, they set fire to a pedestrian gate which is also used to prevent Exmore ponies at the Reserve from escaping.ldquoI am really shocked at this behaviour, she said. ldquoBy the Saturday evening, everyone in the locality had an idea of the widespread damage in the Mournes but these iniduals thought it appropriate to cause more damage and potentially risk another blaze.ldquoI have no idea who these iniduals were and how old they are so I am appealing to people young and old. This is our area and it is being destroyed.Cllr Devlin said that given the ldquoawful scenes witnessed in the Mournes two weekends ago and the huge pressure on the Fire and Rescue Service, she appealed to people to be ldquorespectful and sensible.Cllr Devlin said the ecosystem at the nature reserve was ldquoincredibly delicate and that even the grazing ponies played a pivotal role in what was a very sensitive environment.She also appealed to parents to know where their children are at all times, suggesting they have conversations around the dinner table about the environment and how fortunate they are to live somewhere so beautul and the crucial role everyone has to play in it.Cllr Devlin confirmed that she has been in contact with the National Trust and is concerned that a result of the behaviour of some iniduals, the conservation charity is wasting valuable resources tidying, cleaning and repairing damage.She added: ldquoThis makes no sense and is also very unfair on National Trust rangers whose job it is to conserve and protect our surroundings..prettyPhoto

title: Danny’s delight at lifting top title
story: BALLYNOE native Danny McMenamin capped off a defining season in his young career when he was recently presented with the Conditional Champion Jockey award at Sandown Park racecourse.The up-and-coming jump jockey wrote his name into the history books alongside fellow countrymen Sir AP McCoy and Brian Hughes as a winner of the illustrious prize.Dannyreflected on his crowning moment after he produced an extremely impressive  wins from  rides to finish in first place,  wins ahead of his nearest competition.ldquoItrsquos fantastic, it really is hard to explain just how happy I am that I earned this award, he said.ldquoEvery young lad setting up wants to be the Champion Conditional Jockey, itrsquos every young mans dream. It didnrsquot sink in until I was driving away from the ceremony and it was a great feeling.The jump jockey star first began his interest in horses after watching the races at Downpatrick Racecourse with his family when he was just eight years old. Since then, he carried on visiting the local racetrack with friends and soon caught the racing bug.ldquoI went to a few point-to-pointers with the McCartan family who we know well. It wasnrsquot long after that I got on the saddle for the first time and I got going from there, said Danny.The golden boy started off with Downpatrick trainer Brian Hamilton before working with group one winning flat trainer Ger Lyons in Kildare.On the advice of former Grand National winner Tony Dobbin, Danny then made his big move across the water to Penrith in Cumbria to work under the highly respected trainer Nicky Richards at his famous Greystoke stables.ldquoI was only  when I turned professional and made the move to England.
